{{cleanup|reason=incomplete, lacking sources|date=October 2017}} {{cleanup| reason=what activities?|date=October 2017}} {{cleanup|reason=what are the standards certification process?|date=October 2017}}
[[Image:Norma Oficial Mexicana logo.png|thumb|Norma Oficial Mexicana logo.]] The '''Norma Oficial Mexicana''' (Official Mexican Standard), abbreviated '''NOM''', is the name of each of a series of official, compulsory [[Technical standard|standards]] and regulations for diverse activities in Mexico. They are more commonly referred to as ''NOMs'' or ''normas''.
The standards are prepared by the ''Dirección General de Normas (DGN)'' (General Directorate of Standards), which is the body representing Mexico in the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO).
==Examples== ===Tequila=== In the case of [[tequila]], Mexico's [[Tequila Regulatory Council]] (CRT) regulates production NOMs. The NOM identifier means the tequila meets government standards - but this is not any guarantee of tequila's quality. However, without the NOM stamp of legitimacy, it is not guaranteed that the bottle contains tequila.
All 100% agave tequilas must have a NOM identifier on the bottle. The important laws since 1990 were NOM-006-SCFI-1993 and the later update NOM-006-SCFI-1994 revised in late 2005 NOM-006-SCFI-2005 and the most recent revision in 2012.<ref>[http://www.dof.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=5282165&fecha=13/12/2012 NOM-006-SCFI-2012]</ref>
The number after NOM is the distillery number, assigned by the government. NOM does not indicate the location of the distillery, merely the parent company or - in the case where a company leases space in a plant - the physical plant where the tequila was manufactured.
===Environment=== NOM-137-SEMARNAT-2003 - Issued on the ''[[Official Gazette of the Federation (Mexico)|Official Gazette]]'' on April 29, 2003, and related to [[atmospheric pollution]], [[gas desulfurizing plants]] and sour [[Natural-gas condensate|condensate]], and [[emission standard|control of emissions]] of [[sulfur compounds]].
== References == {{Reflist}} *nom 1465
==External links== *[http://www.mexicanlaws.com/What_is_the_difference.htm Explains the difference between law, regulation and NOM.] *[http://www.ance.org.mx/operacionesint/NOM-NMX.pdf Web page of Asociación de Normalización y Certificación, A.C. (Association for Normalization and Certification), a Mexican entity, where the difference between NOM and NMX is explained.] * [http://www.ianchadwick.com/tequila/nom_dot.htm List of tequila distilleries NOM numbers] * [http://www.natlaw.com/trans/tnapmx3.htm Official Mexican Standard NOM-CCAT-003-ECOL/1993, which establishes the maximum permissible levels of emission of contaminating gases from the exhaust of circulating motor vehicles that use gasoline as fuel.]
[[Category:Standards]] [[Category:Government of Mexico]] [[Category:Certification marks]]
{{Mexico-stub}} {{standard-stub}}

'''Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 85''' (P. Oxy. 85) is part of a series of declarations by various guilds of workmen, written in [[Greek language|Greek]]. The manuscript was written on [[papyrus]] in the form of a sheet. It was discovered in [[Oxyrhynchus]]. The document was written on 26 November 338. Currently it is housed in the Department of Manuscripts of the [[British Museum]] (760) in [[London]].<ref name = Oxy>[http://163.1.169.40/cgi-bin/library?e=d-000-00---0POxy--00-0-0--0prompt-10---4----ded--0-1l--1-en-50---20-about-1708--00031-001-1-0utfZz-8-00&a=d&c=POxy&cl=CL5.1.1&d=HASH66d2209e4ce544c692ae08 P. Oxy. 85] at the Oxyrhynchus Online</ref>
== Description == The letter contains a series of declarations (six of them preserved), addressed to Flavius Eusebius, a ''logistes'' of the Oxyrhynchite ''[[Nome (Egypt)|nome]]'' (the same one as in [[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 86|P. Oxy. 86]]). The guilds state the value of their goods left in stock at the end of a month. Guilds represented are coppersmiths, beer sellers, bakers, oil sellers, and bee-keepers. The declaration from the coppersmiths was written by Aurelius Thonis. The measurements of the fragment are 238 by 220 mm.<ref name = OPI>{{Cite book | last = Grenfell | first = B. P. | authorlink = Bernard Pyne Grenfell | last2 = Hunt | first2 = A. S. | authorlink2 = Arthur Surridge Hunt | title = Oxyrhynchus Papyri I | publisher = Egypt Exploration Fund | year = 1898 | location = London | pages = 147–148 | url = https://archive.org/stream/oxyrhynchuspapyr01grenuoft#page/146/mode/2up | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref>
Papyri P.Oxy. LIV 3772 and SB XVI 12648 are similar to this one.<ref name = Oxy/>
It was discovered by [[Bernard Grenfell|Grenfell]] and [[Arthur Surridge Hunt|Hunt]] in 1897 in Oxyrhynchus. The text was published by Grenfell and Hunt in 1898.<ref name = OPI/> It was also examined by Joachim Hengstl (1985).
== See also == * [[Oxyrhynchus Papyri]] * [[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 84]] * [[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 86]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * Coles, R. A. [https://www.jstor.org/pss/20185893 ''P. Oxy. I 85 Revised''], ''[[Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik]]'' 39 (1980), pp. 115–125.
== External links == * [http://papyri.info/ddbdp/p.oxy;1;85 P.Oxy.1.85 = HGV P.Oxy. 1 85 = Trismegistos 20743]
{{Oxyrhynchus Papyri}}
{{P.Oxy.I.source}}
[[Category:Oxyrhynchus papyri vol. I|085]] [[Category:4th-century manuscripts]] [[Category:British Museum]]

{{italic title}} '''''Practical English Usage''''' is a standard [[reference book]] aimed at foreign learners of English and their teachers written by [[Michael Swan (writer)|Michael Swan]].
Published by [[Oxford University Press]], it has sold over 2 million copies since the first edition was published in 1980.<ref>{{cite web|title=Practical English Usage|url=https://elt.oup.com/catalogue/items/global/grammar_vocabulary/practical_english_usage_4th_edition/|website=[[Oxford University Press]]|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> A new, and greatly extended second edition was published in 1995. A third edition was released in 2005, and a fourth in 2016.
== Feature == It features basic descriptions of [[English grammar]] and usage as well as highlighting various words which are often problematic for non-native speakers. Although the model is basically [[British English]], it explains some of the stylistic differences between British and American usage.
The third edition also takes into account some of the most recent changes within British English, particularly the commonisation of various [[American English]] forms (such as the use of ''like'' as a conjunction - e.g. like I do).
==Influences== In his Acknowledgements for the first edition, Swan refers to the aid given him by "various standard reference books - in particular, the splendid ''[[A Grammar of Contemporary English]]'', by [[Randolph Quirk|Quirk]], Greenbaum, [[Geoffrey Leech|Leech]] and Svartvik" (Longman 1972), and in the second edition, to "the monumental ''[[A Comprehensive Grammar of the English Language]]''" (Longman 1985), by the same authors.
== See also == *[[English grammar]]
==Similar works== *[[The Complete Plain Words]] by [[Ernest Gowers]] *[[A Dictionary of Modern English Usage]] by [[H. W. Fowler]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1980 books]] [[Category:Style guides]] [[Category:Oxford University Press books]]
{{lang-book-stub}}

{{Primary sources|article|date=November 2014}} {{main|United States intervention in Chile}} '''Project FUBELT''' (also known as '''Track II''') is the [[codename]] for the secret [[Central Intelligence Agency]] operations that were to prevent [[Salvador Allende]]'s rise to power before his confirmation and to promote a military coup in Chile.<ref name="Smith, Jr.">{{cite book|last=Smith, Jr.|first=W. Thomas|title=Encyclopedia of the Central Intelligence Agency|year=2003|publisher=Facts on File, Inc.|location=New York|isbn=9781438130187|page=105|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1Jc9wBsImOIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|authorlink=W. Thomas Smith, Jr.|accessdate=January 2, 2015|chapter=FUBELT, Project|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=1Jc9wBsImOIC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA105#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
The highlights of Project FUBELT are cited in declassified [[Federal government of the United States|US government]] documents released by the [[National Security Archive]] on September 11, 1998, 25 years after the coup, as well as in papers uncovered by a 1975 [[US Congress|congressional]] inquiry.
CIA [[memorandum|memoranda]] and reports on Project FUBELT include meetings between [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Henry Kissinger]] and CIA officials, CIA cables to its [[Santiago de Chile|Santiago]] station, and summaries of secret action in 1970, detailing decisions and operations to undermine the [[Chilean presidential election, 1970|election of Salvador Allende]] in September 1970 and to promote a military coup.
In November 1970, the [[US National Security Council]] issued [[National Security Decision Memorandum|National Security Decision Memorandum 93]], which replaced FUBELT.<ref name="Turner">{{cite book |last1=Turner |first1=Michael A. |author-link1= |year=2014 |chapter=Fubelt (Operation) |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=7KDYBAAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA108#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Historical Dictionary of United States Intelligence |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7KDYBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |edition=2nd |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |publication-date= |page=108 |isbn=9780810878907 |accessdate=December 12, 2014}}</ref>
==Revelations from declassified documents== Among the revelations in the formerly secret documents were the following: * Handwritten notes, taken by CIA director [[Richard Helms]], record the orders of President [[Richard Nixon]], to foster a coup in Chile<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch26-01.htm CIA, Notes on Meeting with the President on Chile, September 15, 1970]</ref> * In the first meeting between Helms and high agency officials on the secret operations codenamed "FUBELT", a special task force under the supervision of CIA [[Director of the National Clandestine Service|Deputy Director for Plans]], [[Thomas Karamessines]], is established, headed by veteran agent [[David Atlee Phillips]]. The memorandum notes that the CIA must prepare an action plan for National Security Advisor Henry Kissinger within 48 hours.<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch03-01.htm CIA, Genesis of Project FUBELT, September 16, 1970]</ref> * Henry Kissinger, Thomas Karamessines and [[Alexander Haig]] (military assistant to Henry Kissinger), in a meeting on October 15, 1970, discuss promoting a coup in Chile, known as "Track II" of covert operations. Kissinger orders the CIA to "continue keeping the pressure on every Allende weak spot in sight.<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch06-01.htm CIA, Memorandum of Conversation of Meeting with Henry Kissinger, Thomas Karamessines, and Alexander Haig, October 15, 1970]</ref> * In a secret cable, Thomas Karamessines conveyed Kissinger's orders to CIA station chief in Santiago, [[Henry Hecksher]]: "It is firm and continuing policy that Allende be overthrown by a coup."<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch05-01.htm CIA, Operating Guidance Cable on Coup Plotting, October 16, 1970]</ref> * The CIA ran a series of secret operations intended to push President [[Eduardo Frei Montalva]] to support "a military coup which would prevent Allende from taking office on 3 November."<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch01-01.htm CIA, Report of CIA Chilean Task Force Activities, 15 September to 3 November 1970, November 18, 1970]</ref> * After Salvador Allende's election, the United States considered trying to get Chile expelled from the [[Organization of American States]].<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch20-01.htm Department of State, Memorandum for Henry Kissinger on Chile, December 4, 1970]</ref> * Embassy officers and the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] [[Policy Planning Staff (United States)|Policy Planning office]] called for the cutting off of economic and military assistance to Pinochet's government on human rights grounds, but were overruled by the Ambassador and officials of [[The Pentagon]] and [[United States Department of the Treasury|Treasury Department]].<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/ch04-01.htm National Security Council, Disarray in Chile Policy, July 1, 1975]</ref>
==See also== * [[CIA activities in Chile]] * [[René Schneider#Assassination]] * [[El Mercurio#CIA funding]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * [http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/nsaebb8i.htm Chile and the United States: Declassified Documents Relating to the Military Coup, September 11, 1973] by [[Peter Kornbluh]], [[National Security Archive]]. * National Security Archive Documents: [http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB8/nsaebb8.htm Chile and the United States: Declassified Documents relating to the Military Coup, 1970-1976]
{{1973 Chilean coup d'état}} {{United States intervention in Latin America}}
{{coord|38|57|06|N|77|08|48|W|type:landmark_source:kolossus-eswiki|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:FUBELT}} [[Category:Central Intelligence Agency operations]] [[Category:Classified documents]] [[Category:Presidency of Salvador Allende]] [[Category:Chile–United States relations]] [[Category:Presidency of Richard Nixon]] [[Category:Henry Kissinger]]

{{Italic title}} [[Image:Cover of journal Proverbium, Yearbook of International Proverb Scholarship.png|200px|thumb|right|Cover of ''Proverbium''.]] [[Image:Proverbium Supplement Series sample books.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Sample books from the Proverbium Supplement Series, not in consecutive order.]] '''''Proverbium: Yearbook of International Proverb Scholarship''''' ({{ISSN|0743-782X}}) is an [[academic journal]] covering [[paremiology]], the study of [[proverb]]s. It is published annually by the [[University of Vermont]] and was established in 1985. Since volume 2, the [[editor-in-chief]] is [[Wolfgang Mieder]]. Each volume includes articles on proverbs from around the world, reviews of books, a [[bibliography]] of recent proverb scholarship, and a list of recently (re)published proverb collections.<ref>Bradbury, Nancy Mason. 2002. Transforming Experience into Tradition: Two Theories of Proverb Use and Chaucer’s Practice. ''Oral Tradition'', 17/2: 261-289, see p. 262, fn. 2.</ref>
The journal succeeded ''Proverbium: Bulletin d'Information sur les Recherches Parémiologiques''<ref>p. 1. [[Arvo Krikmann]]. 2009. Proverb semantics: Studies in structure, logic, and metaphor. (Supplement series of Proverbium, 29.) Burlington: University of Vermont.</ref> ({{ISSN|0048-5667}}), which was established by [[Matti Kuusi]] and published occasionally by the [[Finnish Literature Society]] between 1965 and 1975.<ref>p. 217. Outi Lauhakangas. 2013. The Maati Kuusi international database of proverbs. ''Oral Tradition'' 28.2: 217-222.</ref> The journal is one of two ongoing proverb journals listed as a significant source for proverb studies in ''Proverbs: a Handbook'' (page 258).<ref>{{cite book |author=Mieder, Wolfgang |title=Proverbs: A handbook |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport, Conn |year=2004 |pages= |isbn=0-313-32698-3 |oclc=54960019 |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> It is also listed as one of a list of "Proverb Resources" by the Cog Web site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cogweb.ucla.edu/Discourse/Proverbs/ |title=Proverb Resources |publisher=Cogweb.ucla.edu |date=2003-11-08 |accessdate=2012-02-25}}</ref> Also, it is the only current journal listed by the University of Chicago's Defining Wisdom project in their Wisdom Literature Review.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arete.uchicago.edu/files/proverbs.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905021345/http://arete.uchicago.edu/files/proverbs.pdf |archivedate=2012-09-05 |df= }}</ref> It is one of only two journals cited by the International Association of Paremiology on their website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colloquium-proverbs.org/index.php?lang=en |title=Introduction |publisher=Colloquium-proverbs.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-25}}</ref> ''Proverbium'' is indexed by the [[MLA International Bibliography]], [[Répertoire International de Littérature Musicale|RILM Abstracts of Music International]], and Russian Academy of Sciences Bibliographies. Julia Sevilla Muñoz, editor of the journal ''Paremia'', has described it saying, "''Proverbium'' est devenu premier point de recontre et d'échange scientifique pour les vrais spécialistes en parémies."<ref>p. 10. Muñoz, Julia Sevilla. 2002. Préface. ''Proverbes et énoncés sentencieux'', edited by Michel Quitout. Editions L'Harmattan.</ref>
In addition to the journal itself, there is a "Supplement Series" of volumes published by ''Proverbium''. So far, 39 volumes have been published in this book series.
Many of the back issues of ''Proverbium'' are now available online: [http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006930797 Proverbium online]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Cultural journals]] [[Category:American literary magazines]] [[Category:Publications established in 1985]] [[Category:Annual journals]] [[Category:Folklore journals]] [[Category:English-language journals]] [[Category:Published bibliographies]] [[Category:Paremiology]]
{{humanities-journal-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Works */ capitalisation of title to fix link
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox writer | name = Robert Darnton | image = RobertDarnton.jpg | alt = | caption = Darnton in 2006 | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1939|05|10}} | birth_place = New York City, New York City | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Historian, librarian | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = [[Philips Academy]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]
[[University of Oxford]] | period = | genre = | subject = [[Cultural history]], [[18th-century France]], [[history of the book]] | movement = | notableworks = ''[[The Great Cat massacre]]'' | family = | spouse = Eleanor Choate Darnton | partner = | children = | relatives = [[Byron Darnton]] (father)
[[John Darnton]] (brother) | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Robert Choate Darnton''' (born May 10, 1939) is an American [[cultural historian]] and academic librarian who specializes in 18th-century France. He was director of the [[Harvard University Library]] from 2007 to 2016. ==Life== Darnton was born in New York City. He graduated from [[Phillips Academy]] in 1957 and [[Harvard University]] in 1960, attended [[Oxford University]] on a [[Rhodes scholarship]], and earned a PhD (DPhil) in history from Oxford in 1964, where he studied with [[Richard Cobb]], among others. The title of his thesis was ''Trends in radical propaganda on the eve of the French Revolution (1782–1788)''. He worked as reporter at ''[[The New York Times]]'' from 1964 to 1965. Joining the [[Princeton University]] faculty in 1968, he was appointed Shelby Cullom Davis Professor of [[European History]] and was awarded a [[MacArthur Fellowship]] in 1982. He served as President of the [[American Historical Association]] in 1999.{{Cite web |url=http://www.historians.org/info/AHA_History/rdarnton.htm |title=AHA Presidential Addresses: Robert Darnton, 1999 |author1=Robert Darnton |author2=Liz Townsend |author3=Robert Townsend |year=2000 |publisher=American Historical ASsociation |accessdate=August 3, 2011}} On July 1, 2007, he transferred to [[emeritus]] status at Princeton, and was appointed Carl H. Pforzheimer University Professor and director of the [[Harvard University Library]], succeeding [[Sidney Verba]].[http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6446458.html Princeton's Robert Darnton To Succeed Verba as Harvard Library Director – 5/25/2007 – Library Journal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185317/http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6446458.html |date=September 30, 2007 }} In January 2016, [[Ann Blair]] succeeded him as the Carl H. Pforzheimer University Professor.http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2015/11/ann-blair-named-university-professor/ In 1983, he delivered the [[Huizinga Lecture]] in Leiden, the Netherlands, under the title ''The Meaning of Mother Goose''. Darnton is a pioneer in the field of the [[history of the book]]. He is writing about [[electronic publishing]]. He is founder of the Gutenberg-e program, sponsored by [[Mellon Foundation]]. Darnton is a trustee of the [[New York Public Library]].Taylor, Kate. "Amherst President is Expected to Be Named Chief of the New York Public Library," New York Times. October 6, 2010. ==Awards and honors== His first major prize was the [[Leo Gershoy Award]] for ''The Business of Enlightenment'' in 1979. He has also received the [[National Book Critics Circle Award]] for criticism for ''The Forbidden Best-Sellers of Pre-Revolutionary France'' (New York: W.W. Norton, 1996). In 1999, he was named a Chevalier of the [[Légion d'Honneur]], an award given by the French government, in recognition of his work. In 2004 he was awarded the Gutenberg prize by the {{illm|Gutenberg-Gesellschaft|de|lt=International Gutenberg Society}}. In 2005, he received an award for distinguished achievement from the [[American Printing History Association]].[https://www.princeton.edu/main/news/archive/S11/22/88A68/?section=featured Books reveal volumes about times past], Jennifer Greenstein Altmann, Princeton Weekly Bulletin, March 28, 2005. [[Image:02 darnton tuzzi.JPG|thumb|upright=1.3|Prof. Darnton with prof. [[Hans Tuzzi]] at [[Festivaletteratura]] of [[Mantua]], September 8, 2018.]] On February 13, 2012, he was awarded the National Humanities Medal 2011 by President [[Barack Obama]], for his determination to make knowledge accessible to everyone. In 2013, he was awarded the [[Prix mondial Cino Del Duca]] lifetime achievement award.{{Cite web |url=http://lib.harvard.edu/robert-darnton-awarded-prix-mondial-cino-del-duca |title=Robert Darnton Awarded Prix Mondial Cino Del Duca |year=2013 |work=Lib.harvard.edu |publisher=Harvard University Library |accessdate=July 23, 2013 }} In 2016, Darnton received an honorary doctorate from the Faculty of Arts at [[Uppsala University]], Sweden.{{Cite web|title = Faculty of Arts awards honorary doctorates – Uppsala University, Sweden|url = http://www.uu.se/en/research/grants-awards/article/?id=5268&area=2,6,12,16,22&typ=artikel&lang=en|website = uu.se|access-date = 2 February 2016}} ==Family== His brother is the retired ''New York Times'' editor and author [[John Darnton]], and his father was the war correspondent [[Byron Darnton]]. ==Works== * {{Cite book |title=Mesmerism and the End of the Enlightenment in France |year=1995 |origyear=1968 |publisher=Harvard University Press |location=Cambridge, MA |isbn=0-674-56950-4 }} * "In Search of the Enlightenment: Recent Attempts to Create a Social History of Ideas," ''The Journal of Modern History'' Vol. 43, No. 1, March 1971 * {{Cite book |title=The Business of Enlightenment: A Publishing History of the Encyclopédie, 1775–1800 |year=1987 |origyear=1979 |publisher=Harvard Univ. Press |location=Cambridge, MA |isbn=0-674-08786-0 }} * {{Cite book |title=The Literary Underground of the Old Regime |year=1982 |publisher=Harvard University Press |location=Cambridge, MA |isbn=0-674-53656-8 }} * {{Cite book |title=[[The Great Cat Massacre]] and Other Episodes in French Cultural History |year=1984 |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |isbn=0-465-02700-8 }} * Coauthored with [[Daniel Roche]]: {{Cite book |title=Revolution in Print: the Press in France 1775–1800 |year=1989 |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley, CA |isbn=0-520-06430-5 }} * {{Cite book |title=The Kiss of Lamourette: Reflections in Cultural History |year=1990 |publisher=W. {{Infobox Political party |name = Socialist Reich Party of Germany |native_name = Sozialistische Reichspartei Deutschlands | native_name_lang =de |logo = Sozialistische reichspartei.PNG |leader = [[Otto Ernst Remer]]
[[Fritz Dorls]] |foundation = 2 October 1949 |dissolution = 12 September 1952;
''banned'' 23 October 1952 |newspaper = |youth_wing = ''Reichsjugend'' | wing1_title = Paramilitary Wing | wing1 = [[Reichsfront]] |membership = {{circa}} 10,000 |ideology = [[Strasserism]]
[[Neo-fascism]] |merged = [[Deutsche Reichspartei]]Siehe Bericht des bayrischen Verfassungsschutzes, Rechtsextremismus: {{cite web |url=http://www.verfassungsschutz.bayern.de/service/mitteilungen/01573/index.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516131503/http://www.verfassungsschutz.bayern.de/service/mitteilungen/01573/index.php |archivedate=2008-05-16 |df= }} |split = [[Deutsche Rechtspartei]] |position = [[Third Position]] |international = N/A |colors = [[Red]], [[Black]] |colorcode = red |footnotes = |country = West Germany }} The '''Socialist Reich Party of Germany''' ({{lang-de|Sozialistische Reichspartei Deutschlands}}) was a [[West Germany|West German]] [[Strasserism|Strasserist]] political party founded in the aftermath of [[World War II]] in 1949 as an openly [[Neo-fascism|Neo-fascist]] oriented split-off from the national conservative [[Deutsche Rechtspartei|German Right Party]] (DKP-DRP). The SRP was the first party to be banned by the [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|Federal Constitutional Court]] in 1952. == Origins == It was established on 2 October 1949 in [[Hameln]] by [[Otto Ernst Remer]], a former [[Wehrmacht]] major general who had played a vital role in defeating the [[20 July plot]], {{ill|Fritz Dorls|de}}, a former editor of the [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]] newsletter in Lower Saxony, and [[Gerhard Krüger (politician)|Gerhard Krüger]], leader of the [[German Student Union]] under the Third Reich, after they had been excluded from the DKP-DRP. The SRP saw itself as a legitimate heir of the [[Nazi Party]]; most party adherents were former NSDAP members. Its foundation was backed by former [[Luftwaffe]] [[Oberst]] [[Hans-Ulrich Rudel]]. [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-15845-0010, Sozialistische Reichspartei, Dorls, Remer, Westarp.jpg|thumb|left|SRP leaders Dorls (l.), Remer, Wolf von Westarp in August 1952]] == Party platform == The party claimed Chancellor [[Konrad Adenauer]] was a [[United States]] puppet and that Grand Admiral [[Karl Dönitz]] was the last legitimate [[President of Germany (1919–1945)|President]] of the [[German Reich]] appointed by [[Adolf Hitler]].[[Martin A. Lee]], ''[[The Beast Reawakens]]'' (Warner Books, 1998), p. 50. It denied the existence of [[the Holocaust]], claimed that the United States built the gas ovens of the [[Dachau concentration camp]] after the War and that films of [[Internment#Concentration_camp|concentration camps]] were faked.Lee, p. 50. The SRP also advocated Europe, led by a reunited German Reich, as a "[[Third Position|third force]]" against both [[capitalism]] and [[communism]]. It demanded the re-annexation of the [[former eastern territories of Germany]] and a "solution of the [[Jewish question]]". According to [[Karl Dietrich Bracher]], "SRP propaganda concentrated on a vague 'popular socialism' in which the old National Socialists rediscovered well-worn slogans, and also on a nationalism whose championship of Reich and war was but a thinly disguised continuation of the ''[[Lebensraum]]'' ideology".Karl Dietrich Bracher, ''The German Dictatorship. The Origins, Structure, and Consequences of National Socialism'' (Penguin, 1991), p. 581. According to [[Martin A. Lee]], the SRP never openly criticised the [[Soviet Union]]Lee, p. 58. because the Soviet Union funded the SRP as it held anti-American and pro-Soviet views. The [[Communist Party of Germany]], on the other hand, did not receive Soviet funds because it was viewed as "ineffectual".Lee, pp. 74-75.[https://books.google.com/books?id=b8k4rEPvq_8C "Encyclopedia of modern worldwide extremists and extremist groups"], Stephen E. Atkins. Greenwood Publishing Group, 2004. {{ISBN|0-313-32485-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-313-32485-7}}. pp. 273-274 Remer said that if the USSR ever did invade Germany, he would "show the Russians the way to the [[Rhine]]" and that SRP members would "post themselves as traffic policemen, spreading their arms so that the Russians can find their way through Germany as quickly as possible".Lee, p. 65.T. H. Tetens, ''The New Germany and the Old Nazis'' (London: Secker & Warburg, 1962), p. 78. == Election results == Dorls had been elected as a DKP-DRP deputy to the [[Bundestag]] parliament in the [[West German federal election, 1949|1949 election]]. The SRP gained a second seat in parliament, when MP [[Fritz Rössler]] (alias Dr. Franz Richter) joined the party in 1950. In May 1951 it won 16 seats in the [[Lower Saxony]] state assembly ([[Landtag]]) election, receiving 11.0% of the votes with strongholds in the [[Stade (region)|Stade region]] (21.5%; [[Verden (district)|Verden district]]: 27.7%). In October 1951 it gained 7.7% of the votes in [[Bremen (state)|Bremen]] and won 8 seats in the city's [[Bürgerschaft of Bremen|Bürgerschaft]] parliament. == Membership == The SRP had about ten thousand members. Affiliated associations were the ''Reichsfront'' [[paramilitary]] organisation and the ''Reichsjugend'' [[youth wing]], which were banned by decision of the [[Federal Ministry of the Interior (Germany)|Federal Minister of the Interior]] on 4 May 1951. On the same day, the [[Cabinet of Germany|West German cabinet]] decided to file an application to the Federal Constitutional Court to find the SRP anti-constitutional and to impose a ban. On 23 October 1952 the court according to Article 21 Paragraph 2 of the [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany|Basic Law]] adjudicated the party unconstitutional and dissolved, prohibited the founding of any successor organisations, withdraw all Bundestag and Landtag mandates and seized the party's assets (BVerfGE 2, 1). In view of the verdict, the SRP leaders had already declared the Party dissolved on 12 September. ==See also== * [[Black Front]] == Notes == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://archive.org/details/GermanysNewNazis ''Germany's New Nazis''] 1951 pamphlet about the SRP and other neo-nazi groups by the [[Anglo-Jewish Association]] {{NSDAP}} {{Neo-Nazism}} {{German far right}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Banned political parties in Germany]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Germany]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1949]] [[Category:1949 establishments in West Germany]] [[Category:Far-right political parties in Germany]] [[Category:Fascist parties in Germany]] [[Category:Banned far-right parties]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1952]] [[Category:1952 disestablishments in West Germany]] [[Category:Neo-Nazism in Germany]] [[Category:German nationalist political parties]] [[Category:Neo-fascist parties]] [[Category:Third Position]]

{{Use British English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Spice World | image = spice_world.jpg | alt = A sparkling Union Jack flag with four women standing in front and a red haired woman crouched down in front | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Bob Spiers]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Uri Fruchtmann]] * [[Barnaby Thompson]] }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Kim Fuller]] * '''Additional writing:''' * Jamie Curtis }} | based on = {{based on|An idea|the [[Spice Girls]] and Kim Fuller}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Victoria Beckham|Posh Spice]] * [[Emma Bunton|Baby Spice]] * [[Melanie C|Sporty Spice]] * [[Geri Halliwell|Ginger Spice]] * [[Mel B|Scary Spice]] * [[Richard E. Grant]] * [[Alan Cumming]] * [[George Wendt]] * [[Claire Rushbrook]] * [[Mark McKinney]] * [[Roger Moore]]}} | music = [[Paul Hardcastle]] | cinematography = Clive Tickner | editing = Andrea MacArthur | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[PolyGram Filmed Entertainment]] * Fragile Films * [[Icon Entertainment International]] * Spice Productions }} | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|1997|12|15|UK premiere|1997|12|26|United Kingdom}} | runtime = 93 minutes<!-- Theatrical runtime: 92:49 --><ref name="bbfc"/> | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = $25 million<ref>{{cite web |last=Pappas |first=Ben |url=https://www.forbes.com/global/1999/0322/0206060a.html |title=Star power, star brands |work=[[Forbes]] |date=22 March 1999}}</ref> | gross = $151 million<ref name="ewspice"/><ref name="ofi"/><ref name=telegraph2017/> }} '''''Spice World''''' is a 1997 British [[Musical film|musical]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Bob Spiers]] and written by [[Kim Fuller]] and Jamie Curtis. The film stars [[Pop music|pop]] [[girl group]] the [[Spice Girls]] who all play themselves. The film—made in a similar vein to [[The Beatles]]' ''[[A Hard Day's Night (film)|A Hard Day's Night]]'' (1964)—depicts a series of fictional events leading up to a major concert at [[London]]'s [[Royal Albert Hall]], liberally interspersed with dream sequences and [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]] as well as [[Surrealism|surreal]] moments and humorous asides.
This is the second feature-length film directed by Spiers, following ''[[That Darn Cat (1997 film)|That Darn Cat]]'' (1997). The film features [[Richard E. Grant]], [[Claire Rushbrook]], [[Naoko Mori]], [[Meat Loaf]], [[Barry Humphries]], and [[Alan Cumming]] in supporting roles. Filming took place in [[London]] for six of the eight filming weeks and also inside [[Twickenham Studios]], as well as at over 40 famous British landmarks. Shooting featured several fourteen-hour shooting sessions and a constant, heavy media presence due to the Spice Girls' large popularity at the time.
The film premiered on 15 December 1997 and was released to British cinemas on the British holiday [[Boxing Day]] (26 December). In North America, the film was distributed by [[Columbia Pictures]], [[PolyGram Filmed Entertainment]], and [[Icon Entertainment International]] and premiered on 23 January 1998. In the United States, ''Spice World'' became a box office success and broke the record for the highest-ever weekend debut for [[Super Bowl]] weekend with box office sales of $10,527,222. The film grossed $151 million at the box office worldwide and over $100 million including DVD sales.<ref name="ofi">Spice Girls Official. [http://www.thespicegirls.com/facts/biography Biography]. 19 Management Entertainment.</ref> Despite being a box office success, the film received primarily negative reviews.
To celebrate its 20th Anniversary in 2017, ''Spice World'' was given a limited release across the United Kingdom showing at Odeon Cinemas. The film grossed just shy of £1 million bringing the total gross income $151 million worldwide.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==Plot== The film begins with the [[Spice Girls]] performing "[[Too Much (Spice Girls song)|Too Much]]" on ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', but they become dissatisfied with the burdens of fame and fortune. Meanwhile, sinister newspaper owner Kevin McMaxford ([[Barry Humphries]]) is attempting to ruin the girls' reputation for his newspaper's ratings. McMaxford dispatches photographer Damien ([[Richard O'Brien]]) to take pictures and tape recordings of the girls. Less threatening but more annoying is Piers Cuthbertson-Smyth ([[Alan Cumming]]), who stalks the girls along with his camera crew, hoping to use them as subjects for his next project. At the same time, the girls' uptight manager, Clifford ([[Richard E. Grant]]) and his sympathetic assistant Deborah ([[Claire Rushbrook]]), are fending off two over-eager Hollywood writers, Martin Barnfield and Graydon ([[George Wendt]] and [[Mark McKinney]]), who relentlessly pitch absurd plot ideas for a feature film for the Spice Girls.
Amid this, the girls must prepare for their live concert at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in three days, the biggest performance of their career. At the heart of it, the constant practices, traveling, publicity appearances, and other burdens of celebrity affect the girls on a personal level, preventing them from spending much time with their pregnant best friend, Nicola ([[Naoko Mori]]), who is due to give birth soon. Throughout the busy schedule, the girls attempt to ask Clifford for time off to spend with Nicola and relax, but Clifford refuses after talking with the head of the girls' record label, the cryptic and eccentric "Chief" ([[Roger Moore]]). The stress and overwork compound, which culminate in a huge argument between Clifford and the girls. The girls suddenly storm out on the evening before their gig at the Albert Hall.
The girls separately think back on their humble beginnings and their struggle to the top. They reunite by chance outside the now-abandoned café where they practiced during their childhood years, they reconcile, and decide to take Nicola out dancing. However, Nicola goes into labor at the nightclub and is rushed to the hospital in the girls' bus, giving birth to a healthy baby girl. When [[Emma Bunton|Emma]] notices that the delivery "doctor" has a camera, the girls realize that he is Damien, who runs off with the girls in hot pursuit, only to hit his head after accidentally colliding with an empty stretcher. When Damien sees the girls standing over him, he tells them that they have made him see the error of his ways, and he goes after McMaxford, who is subsequently fired in a "Jacuzzi scandal".
After noticing the girls' bus driver, Dennis ([[Meat Loaf]]) is missing, [[Victoria Beckham|Victoria]] decides to take the wheel. It becomes a race against time as Victoria drives like a maniac through London. While approaching [[Tower Bridge]], the bridge begins to raise to let a boat through the [[River Thames]]. Victoria drives up the bridge and over the gap. The bus finally lands safely on the other side, but when Emma opens a trapdoor in the floor, she discovers a bomb, and the girls scream before Emma slams the trapdoor shut again.
The girls finally arrive at the Royal Albert Hall for their performance and run up the steps. However, the girls have one more obstacle to overcome: a London policeman ([[Kevin McNally]]) charges the girls with "dangerous driving, criminal damage, flying a bus without a license, and frightening the pigeons". Emma pushes forward and tells the policeman that she and the other girls were late for their performance at the Albert Hall. Emma smiles at the policeman, and he lets the girls off for their performance. The film ends when the girls perform their song "[[Spice Up Your Life]]" at the start of their Royal Albert Hall concert broadcast live on television around the world.
The supporting cast later talk about the girls' film during the closing credits. [[Melanie Chisholm|Mel C]] breaks the [[fourth wall]] and tells the other girls that the outgoing audience is watching them. The girls talk to the audience, commenting on "those two in the back row snogging" and on one's dress, and discuss their film, just minutes before the bomb in their bus explodes.

Grant]] as Clifford * [[Claire Rushbrook]] as Deborah * [[Roger Moore]] as The Chief * [[Naoko Mori]] as Nicola * [[Meat Loaf]] as Dennis * [[Barry Humphries]] as Kevin McMaxford * [[Jason Flemyng]] as Brad {{col-break}} * [[Richard O'Brien]] as Damien * [[Alan Cumming]] as Piers Cuthbertson-Smyth * [[George Wendt]] as Martin Barnfield * [[Mark McKinney]] as Graydon * [[Steven O'Donnell (actor)|Steven O'Donnell]] as Jess * Gary Crombie as Roy MacInerney * [[Michael Barrymore]] as Mr. Step * [[Jools Holland]] as Musical director * [[Kevin McNally]] as Policeman / ''Dance of the Goblins'' disassociator * [[Kevin Allen (actor)|Kevin Allen]] as Gainer * [[Peter Sissons]] as himself * [[Neil Mullarkey]] as Barnaby * [[Richard Briers]] as Bishop {{col-break}} * [[Dominic West]] as Photographer * [[Bill Paterson (actor)|Bill Paterson]] as Brian * [[Jonathan Ross (television presenter)|Jonathan Ross]] as himself * [[Elvis Costello]] as Bartender * [[Elton John]] as himself * [[Bob Geldof]] as himself * [[Bob Hoskins]] as himself * [[Jennifer Saunders]] as Fashionable woman * [[Hugh Laurie]] as Poirot * [[Stephen Fry]] as Judge {{col-end}}
==Music== An official motion picture soundtrack has not been released, since their second studio album, ''[[Spiceworld (album)|Spiceworld]]'', was released at the time, heavily promoted and served as the film's soundtrack. The only song from ''Spiceworld'' not to appear in the film is "[[Move Over]]". The songs appearing in the film are in order of appearance. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * Spice Girls - "[[Too Much (Spice Girls song)|Too Much (Spice World Version)]]" <small>(''Opening sequence'')</small> * Spice Girls - "Do It" * Spice Girls - "[[Say You'll Be There|Say You'll Be There (Unplugged Concert Version)]]" * Spice Girls - "[[Mama (Spice Girls song)|Mama]]" * Spice Girls - "Denying" * Spice Girls - "Saturday Night Divas" * Spice Girls - "[[Stop (Spice Girls song)|Stop]]" * Spice Girls - "[[2 Become 1]]" * Spice Girls - "[[I'm the Leader of the Gang (I Am)]]" {{col-break}} * Spice Girls - "Never Give Up on the Good Times" * Spice Girls - "[[Military cadence|Sound Off]]" * [[Millie (singer)|Millie Small]] - "[[My Boy Lollipop]]" * Spice Girls - "[[Viva Forever]]" * Spice Girls - "[[Wannabe|Wannabe (Demo Version)]]" * Spice Girls - "[[Who Do You Think You Are (Spice Girls song)|Who Do You Think You Are (Morales Club Mix Edit)]]" * Spice Girls - "[[Spice Up Your Life|Spice Up Your Life (Live @ Albert Hall)]]" * Spice Girls - "The Lady Is a Vamp" <small>(''Closing titles'')</small> {{col-end}}
==Production==
===Development=== [[File:Spiceworld-gerihalliwell-outfit.jpg|thumb|Geri Halliwell's red swimsuit from the film.]] Spiers had been working in America on the Disney film ''[[That Darn Cat (1997 film)|That Darn Cat]]'' at the peak of the Spice Girls' popularity. He was unaware of the group when first offered the job until his friend [[Jennifer Saunders]] advised that he take it. He arrived at a meeting with them in a New York hotel unaware of what they looked like.<ref>Bob Spiers and Stacey Adair, ''[[Joking Apart]]'', Series 2 Episode 2, DVD audio commentary, replaydvd.co.uk</ref>
===Casting=== [[Frank Bruno]] was originally cast as the tour bus driver, but withdrew after a security guard prevented his son Franklin having an on-set photo taken with the girls.
Mentions of [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess Diana]] and scenes including the designer [[Gianni Versace]] had to be edited out in post-production following their deaths before the release of the film.<ref name="20 things">{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2013/01/20-things-you-didnt-know-about-spice-world/gary-glitter |title=20 Things You Didn't Know About "Spice World" |publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex Magazine]] |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref>
The film reunited [[Meat Loaf]] and [[Richard O'Brien]], who co-starred in the 1975 classic film ''[[The Rocky Horror Picture Show]]''. The film also reunited O'Brien and [[Barry Humphries]], who costarred in the ''Rocky Horror'' follow-up, ''[[Shock Treatment]]'' (1981).
"Their company rang me up and asked if I would be in it", remarked [[Elvis Costello]] of his cameo. "I wouldn't have thought I was the kind of face you would get to do a cornflakes advert. Maybe twenty years ago. I was surprised."<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Paul|last=Du Noyer]]|authorlink=Paul Du Noyer|title=Cash for questions|magazine=[[Q (magazine)|Q]]|issue=137|date=February 1998|page=15}}</ref>
====Gary Glitter controversy==== [[Gary Glitter]] filmed a four-minute [[cameo appearance]] as himself, but shortly before the film was to be released he was [[Gary Glitter#Child pornography arrest and conviction|arrested on child pornography offences]]. The Spice Girls and the production team agreed that his cameo should be deleted from the final print. The performance of Glitter's "[[I'm the Leader of the Gang (I Am)]]" was retained.<ref name="gary glitter">{{cite web|url=https://uk.movies.yahoo.com/the-truth-behind-the-lost-gary-glitter-cameo-in-142328383.html |title=The Truth Behind The Deleted Gary Glitter Cameo In The Spice Girls Movie |publisher=[[Yahoo! Movies]] |date=5 May 2016 |accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref>
===The Spice Bus=== [[File:Spice Bus.jpg|thumb|The bus used in the Spice World movie.]] Official toy versions of the Spice Bus were produced upon the release of the movie.<ref name="spice bus toys">{{cite web|url=http://www.vivaspice.net/guide/official/toys/buses.htm |title=Toy Spice Buses |publisher=VivaSpice.net |accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> On 18 July 2014, the actual Spice Bus used in the film was put on permanent display at [[Island Harbour Marina]], on the [[Isle of Wight]], England.<ref name="spice bus display">[http://www.island-harbour.co.uk/spice/ The Spice Bus]. Island Harbour. Retrieved 25 June 2016.</ref>
==Release==
===Rating=== In the United Kingdom, ''Spice World'' was granted a [[History of British film certificates#1994-2002|PG certificate]] by the [[British Board of Film Classification]] for "mild bad language, mild sex references".<ref name="bbfc">{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/spice-world-movie-1997-0 | title=''SPICE WORLD - THE MOVIE'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=27 November 1997 | accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> In the United States, it received a [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#MPAA film ratings|PG rating]] from the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] for "some vulgarity, brief nudity and language".
===Box office=== Spiceworld was a number-one box office success in the United Kingdom, grossing more than £6.8 million during its opening weekend on Boxing Day, 1997. The film was also successful at the box office in the United States, breaking the record at that time for the highest-ever weekend debut for Super Bowl weekend (25 January 1998), with box office sales of $10,527,222.<ref name="IMDb opening weekend">[https://www.imdb.com/BusinessThisDay?day=25&month=January Opening weekend box office sales in the US]. [[Internet Movie Database]]. Retrieved 25 June 2006.</ref> The film took in total $151 million at the box office worldwide.<ref name="ewspice">[[Entertainment Weekly]]. Benjamin Svetkey. ''Pag. 2'' [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,283983_2,00.html Cover Story: Tour Divorce?]. 17 July 1998. Retrieved 24 January 2009.</ref><ref name="IMDB Business">IMDb. [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120185/business ''Spiceworld: The Movie'' box office]. [[Internet Movie Database]]. Retrieved 1 July 2008.</ref>
The film was released on VHS in May 1998 in many regions including the UK, Germany, Spain, the Netherlands, Japan and Australia. In June 1998, it came out on VHS in the US and Canada. Despite concerns that the high-profile departure of Halliwell from the Spice Girls would affect sales, global demand for the VHS was high.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=YQ4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA120&dq=spice+girls+world+music+awards&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPgvu7pZvSAhXIRo8KHSj3CnkQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=spice%20girls%20world%20music%20awards&f=false|title=With Spice Girls Down to Four, Sales Still Ride High (pg. 8, 120) |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=12 June 1998 |accessdate=18 February 2017 }}</ref> In the UK, the film was number one on the video charts for six consecutive weeks,<ref>[http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/video-chart/19980705/12/ Official Video Chart Top 100: 31 May 1998 - 11 July 1998]. [[Official Charts Company]]. Retrieved 17 February 2017.</ref> was certified 11x Platinum, and became the ninth best-selling video of 1998.<ref>[http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/end-of-year-video-chart/19980104/30012/ End of Year Video Chart Top 100 - 1998]. [[Official Charts Company]]. Retrieved 17 February 2017.</ref> In the US, the film peaked at number one on the video charts for five consecutive weeks<ref> * {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=-AkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA64&dq=spice+world+video+sales&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBv6Siz5vSAhXKQY8KHVpDDog4FBDoAQgbMAE#v=onepage&q=spice%20world%20video%20sales&f=false|title=Top Video Sales: 11 July 1998 |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=11 July 1998 |accessdate=18 February 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=9wkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA66&dq=spice+world+video+sales&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBv6Siz5vSAhXKQY8KHVpDDog4FBDoAQgjMAM#v=onepage&q=spice%20world%20video%20sales&f=false|title=Top Video Sales: 18 July 1998 |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=18 July 1998 |accessdate=18 February 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=9gkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA72&dq=spice+world+video+sales&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj0-9-G0JvSAhXHMY8KHRF6AxAQ6AEIODAI#v=onepage&q=spice%20world%20video%20sales&f=false|title=Top Video Sales: 25 July 1998 |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=25 July 1998 |accessdate=18 February 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=8wkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA73&dq=spice+world+video+sales&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiro-OZzpvSAhWIwI8KHQZ3CpIQ6AEINjAH#v=onepage&q=spice%20world%20video%20sales&f=false|title=Top Video Sales: 1 August 1998 |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=1 August 1998 |accessdate=18 February 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=8AkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=spice+world+video+sales&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjdu7ez0JvSAhWHro8KHfAKB6E4FBDoAQg7MAk#v=onepage&q=spice%20world%20video%20sales&f=false|title=Top Video Sales: 8 August 1998 |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=8 August 1998 |accessdate=18 February 2017 }}</ref> and was the fifth best-selling video of 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=Fw0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA52&dq=1998+best+vhs+selling+spice+world&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwinxoG7zJvSAhXFMI8KHQzrBRcQ6AEIGDAA#v=onepage&q=1998%20best%20vhs%20selling%20spice%20world&f=false|title=The Year in Video: Top Video Sales |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=9 January 1999 |accessdate=18 February 2017 }}</ref>
===2017 re-release=== In 2017, the film was screened at various cinemas in the UK and Australia to mark its 20th anniversary.<ref name=telegraph2017>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2017/09/29/spice-world-20-spice-girls-made-movie-history/|title=Five go mad on camera: how the Spice Girls made Spice World|work=The Telegraph|first=Alice|last=Vincent|date=29 September 2017}}</ref> Plans to re-release the movie in other worldwide territories are currently underway.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}}
===Critical reception=== {{Video game reviews | rev1 = [[AllMovie]] | rev1Score = {{rating|2|5}}<ref name="allmovie" /> | rev2 = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | rev2Score = (35%)<ref name="rotten" /> }} The film received generally negative reviews from critics. Film review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave ''Spice World'' a rating of 35% based on reviews from 63 critics, with an average rating of 4.5 out of 10.<ref name="rotten">{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/spice_world/ | title=Spice World (1998) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Flixster]] | accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a 32 out of 100 rating, based on 16 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/spice-world | title=Spice World Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref> [[AllMovie]] gave it two out of five stars.<ref name="allmovie">{{AllMovie title|160114|Spice World}}</ref>
Noted American [[Film criticism|film critic]] [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film one-half of a star and listed ''Spice World'' as one of his most hated films, saying: "The Spice Girls are easier to tell apart than the [[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles|Mutant Ninja Turtles]], but that is small consolation: What can you say about five women whose principal distinguishing characteristic is that they have different names? They occupy ''Spice World'' as if they were watching it: They're so detached they can't even successfully [[Lip sync|lip-synch]] their own songs." And when he reviewed the film on his and [[Gene Siskel]]'s film critique programme ''[[Siskel & Ebert]]'', only three weeks into 1998, he declared that he had already seen the worst film of that year, and called it "an entertainment-free dead zone". Ebert would include this film on the ''Worst of 1998'' special; but he chose ''[[Armageddon (1998 film)|Armageddon]]'' as the worst film of 1998.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050811/COMMENTARY/50808002 | work=Chicago Sun-Times | title=Ebert's Most Hated}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F19980123%2FREVIEWS%2F801230303%2F1023&AID1=%2F19980123%2FREVIEWS%2F801230303%2F1023&AID2= | work=Chicago Sun-Times | title=Spice World}}</ref>
[[Janet Maslin]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' stated that the film "is pleasant and painless enough to amuse ardent fans, who figure in the film quite often." She also noted that while it got a PG rating in the [[United States]], "nothing about it should disturb its target audience of media-wise, fun-loving 8-year-old girls."<ref>{{cite news | date = 23 January 1998 | author = [[Janet Maslin]] | work = [[The New York Times]] | title = 'Spice World': Hits and Hairdos on the Spice Rack | url = https://www.nytimes.com/library/film/012398spice-film-review.html }}</ref> Writing for ''[[Sight and Sound]]'', in a positive review, Mark Sinker placed it alongside [[The Monkees]]' 1968 cult film ''[[Head (film)|Head]]''. He went on to say that it "sends up the amiable idiocy of pop packaging - and the slow witted mass-media response to it" and it was "tirelessly generous in its energy".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sinker|first=Mark|date=February 1998|title=Spice World|journal=Sight and Sound|pages=49|issn=0037-4806}}</ref>
[[Derek Elley]], resident film critic for ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', gave the film mixed reviews, calling the film "bright and breezy" and "as timely but evanescent as the [[Cool Britannia]] culture it celebrates". He stated that the film would "delight the Fab Five's pre-pubescent fans" but that it would "be forgotten within six months".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/1997/film/reviews/spice-world-1200452214/| work=Variety|title=Review: ‘Spice World’|last=Elley|first=Derek|date=18 December 1997}}</ref>
===Accolades=== The film has been listed in [[Golden Raspberry Awards]] founder [[John J.B. Wilson|John Wilson]]'s book ''The Official Razzie Movie Guide'' as one of "The 100 Most Enjoyably Bad Movies Ever Made".<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=John|title=The Official Razzie Movie Guide: Enjoying the Best of Hollywood's Worst |year=2005|publisher=Grand Central Publishing|isbn=0-446-69334-0}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Subject ! Result |- |rowspan=11|[[Golden Raspberry Award]] |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actress|Worst Actress]] |rowspan=3|[[Spice Girls]] |{{won}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst New Star|Worst New Star]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=3|[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Original Song|Worst Original Song]] <small>("[[Too Much (Spice Girls song)|Too Much]]")</small> |{{nom}} |- |[[Paul Wilson (musician)|Paul Wilson]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Andy Watkins]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actor|Worst Supporting Actor]] |[[Roger Moore]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screen Couple/Ensemble|Worst Screen Couple]] |Any combination of two people, body parts or fashion accessories |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screenplay|Worst Screenplay]] |Jamie Curtis |{{nom}} |- |[[Kim Fuller]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture|Worst Picture]] |[[Uri Fruchtmann]] |{{nom}} |- |Barnaby Thompson |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=1|[[Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Award]] |Favorite Movie Actress |rowspan=1|[[Spice Girls]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=1|[[Blockbuster Entertainment Award]] |Favorite Movie Actress in a Comedy |rowspan=1|[[Spice Girls]] |{{nom}} |- |} ==Legacy== The film, while being negatively reviewed, is remembered fondly by many who were part of its target audience of younger pop fans at the time of its release. It has arguably achieved cult status as a commentary on [[Popular culture|pop culture]], and is ultimately a more cohesive film by a pop group than predecessors like [[The Beatles]]' ''[[A Hard Day's Night (film)|A Hard Day's Night]]'' or ''[[Magical Mystery Tour (film)|Magical Mystery Tour]]''.<ref>[https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/gywe57/spice-girls-surreal-moments-from-cult-classic-spice-world Spice World cult film on broadly.vice.com]</ref><ref>[https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/mbpwda/how-the-spice-world-movie-became-a-deranged-postmodern-masterpiece Spice World chef d'oeuvre on broadly.vice.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/crew-members-explain-spice-world-still-weird-20-years Spice World review on interviewmagazine.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.getsurrey.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/spice-world-movie-air-vue-13415107 Spice World a real cult classic movie on getsurrey.co.uk]</ref><ref>[https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/spice-world-movie-vue-cinema-13414469 Spice World movie on chroniclelive.co.uk]</ref><ref>[https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/a55766/spice-world-is-better-than-a-hard-days-night/ Spice World a brillant movie on esquire.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/our-region/edinburgh/spice-world-turns-20-film-to-be-screened-in-edinburgh-1-4526360 Spice World a cult film on scotsman.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/spice-world-movie-shown-belfast-13415276 Spice World on belfastliveco.uk]</ref><ref>[https://www.blogto.com/events/screen-queens-spice-world/ Spice World the movie clut film on blogto.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.buzzfeed.com/mjs538/why-spice-world-is-a-cinematic-masterpiece Spice World a masterpiece on buzzfeed.com]</ref>
==See also== * [[Spice Girls filmography]] * [[List of films featuring extraterrestrials]]
==Home media== ''Spice World: The 10th Anniversary Edition'' was released on [[DVD]] on 19 November 2007 in the United Kingdom and Australia and on 27 November 2007 in the United States.
''Spice World: The 20th Anniversary Edition'' will be released on Blu Ray in the UK and Australia in December 2018 to mark the 20th anniversary of the VHS release. It will feature a new documentary about the film with all five [[Spice Girls]] and many apecial guests who featured in the film including [[Jennifer Saunders]] , [[Richard E. Grant]], and [[Meat Loaf]].

{{italic title}} {{more footnotes|date=October 2015}} [[Image:Stielers Hand-Atlas Hundertjahr-Ausgabe Einband.png|thumb|180px|''Stielers Handatlas'' 10th Edition]] [[Image:India and Inner Asia.jpg|thumb|180px|Map of [[India]] and [[Asia]], printed in [[Adolf Stieler|''Stieler's'']] ''Atlas'']] [[Image:Stielers Handatlas 1891 59.jpg|thumb|180px|Map of [[Iran]] and [[Turan]] in [[Qajar dynasty]] drawn by [[Adolf Stieler]]]] '''''Stielers Handatlas''''' (after [[Adolf Stieler]], 1775–1836), formally titled '''''Hand-Atlas über alle Theile der Erde und über das Weltgebäude''''' (''Handy atlas of all parts of the world and of the universe''), was the leading German world [[atlas]] of the last three decades of the 19th and the first half of the 20th century. Published by [[Justus Perthes]] of Gotha (established 1785 and still existing there) it went through ten editions from 1816 to 1945.<ref name=esp />{{rp|290/2}} As with many 19th century publications, an edition was issued in parts; for example, the eighth edition was issued in 32 monthly parts.
== Editions == The earliest edition, by Stieler and [[Christian Gottlieb Reichard]],<ref name=esp>{{cite book|last1=Espenhorst|first1=Jürgen|title=Petermann's Planet|date=2003|publisher=Pangaea|location=Schwerte|isbn=3-930401-35-5}}</ref>{{rp|326/2}} was published as separate plates from 1817 to 1823.<ref name=esp />{{rp|222/1}} There were 47 maps, though the intention had been to publish 50.<ref name=esp />{{rp|222/1}} After Stieler's death Friedrich von Stülpnagel (1786–1865) edited the first (1834-1845) edition,<ref name=esp />{{rp|238/1}} and the second (1845–47) with 107 maps.<ref name=esp />{{rp|239/2}}. [[August Heinrich Petermann|Petermann]] contributed to the third (1854–62) edition<ref name=esp />{{rp|222/1}} containing 83 maps, the fourth (1864-67)<ref name=esp />{{rp|247/1}} and the fifth (1868-74),<ref name=esp />{{rp|248/2}} each with 84 maps.
However, it was not until the sixth edition (1871–75, 90 maps), edited by [[August Petermann]] (1822–78), [[Hermann Berghaus]] (1828–1890) and Carl Vogel (1828–1897), that the work reached the high scientific level and the unsurpassed relief ''Stieler's Atlas'' is famous for. A seventh edition was issued 1879-82; an eighth 1888-91 (both 95 maps) under the direction of Hermann Berghaus, Vogel and Hermann Habenicht (1844–1917). Although the printing industry had already changed to [[lithography]] for some time, some maps in ''Stieler's Atlas'' were still reproduced by [[copper-plate]] printing on hand presses with hand colouring into the 1890s.
The ninth edition (1901–05), edited by Habenicht, with one hundred maps, over double the number of the initial edition, was the first one printed on cylinder machines by means of lithography, which halved the price and made the ''Stieler'' accessible to a broad public. 16 maps hereof were exclusively translated to English, transferred to [[Imperial units]] and became part the [[Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition|11th edition]] of the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' (1910–1911).<ref>Wolfgang Lierz: ''Karten aus Stielers Hand-Atlas in der „{{sic|Encyclopaedia Britannica|hide=yes}}“.'' In: ''Cartographica Helvetica.'' Heft 29, 2004, {{ISSN|1015-8480}}, S. 27–34 [http://www.e-periodica.ch/digbib/view?pid=chl-001:2004:29-30::28 online].</ref> [[Hermann Haack]] (1872–1966) edited the tenth (centenary) edition (1920–25, 108 maps), with an index to 320,000 entries being the most comprehensive world atlas of modern times.
English versions of the ninth and tenth editions appeared as ''Stieler's Atlas of Modern Geography'', and editions with similar titles were also issued in French, Italian and Spanish. An international edition (1934–1940) remained with 84 of the 114 maps planned incomplete due to wartime circumstances. The work was engraved on 432 copper plates which have been preserved. {{Clear}}
==External links== *[http://www.davidrumsey.com/worldatlases.html DavidRumsey.com The 1875 6th Edition Handatlas], and many other maps and atlases, are viewable online *[http://www.maproom.org/00/09/index.php maproom.org 1891 8th Edition Handatlas] *[http://www.handatlas.de/ handatlas.de Web archive of the great German Hand-Atlases]. ''Stielers'' of all decades online.
== References == {{commons|Stielers Handatlas 1891}} *Espenhorst, E; ''Petermann's Planet'' (Schwerte, 2003). *Köhler, F; ''Gothaer Wege in Geographie und Kartographie'' (Gotha, 1987) *Suchy, G; ''Gothaer Geographen und Kartographen'' (Gotha, 1985) {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Atlases]]

revision.text:
{{italictitle}} '''''The Cuisines of Mexico''''' is the first of [[Diana Kennedy]]’s nine cookbooks, credited with introducing Americans to [[Mexican cuisine|Mexican food]] beyond [[Tex-Mex]].
==Background to the book== The book was the result of Kennedy’s love of Mexican food, which she discovered when she moved to [[Mexico City]] to live with her husband, ''New York Times'' reporter Paul P. Kennedy in 1957. The couple moved to New York City by the end of 1965, with Paul dying in 1967 of cancer<ref name=schoeder>{{cite web |author= Eric James Schroeder |title= "Every Recipe Has a Story": An Interview with Diana Kennedy |publisher= Writing on the Edge |location= University of California, Davis |url= http://woe.ucdavis.edu/samples/DianaKennedyInterview.pdf |accessdate= November 2, 2015 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151121235812/http://woe.ucdavis.edu/samples/DianaKennedyInterview.pdf |archivedate= November 21, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref name=theexpat>{{cite web |author=Beth Bracklauer |title=The Expat:Diana Kennedy |publisher=Saveur magazine |date=August 12, 2012 |url= http://www.saveur.com/article/Travels/Diana-Kennedy |accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref>
To make a living, Kennedy began teaching Mexican cooking classes in her Upper West Side apartment, with the cuisine quite novel at the time.<ref name=schoeder/><ref name=theexpat/> Although ''New York Times'' food writer [[Craig Claiborne]] once mentioned to her that she should write a Mexican cookbook and encouraged her cooking classes. The book began to come together after then-poetry editor at [[Harper (publisher)|Harper and Row]] Fran McCullough took one of her classes and offered to be her editor. The two would eventually work on Kennedy’s first five cookbooks.<ref name=schoeder/><ref name=guillermoprieto>{{cite journal |author=Alma Guillermoprieto |title= Disappearing dishes |journal= The New Yorker |location= New York |date=August 2002 |volume= 78 |issue=24 |page=98 }}</ref><ref name=theexpat/> Although Kennedy had been collecting recipes since her time in Mexico City, she decided to go to Mexico to do further research.<ref name=schoeder/> This research, she believes, is what separates her from other cookbook writers is that she has taken the time and effort to explore Mexico and do field research on how the cuisine varies.<ref name=kracklauer>{{cite web |author=Beth Bracklauer |title=The Interview:Diana Kennedy |publisher=Saveur magazine |date=September 3, 2012 |url= http://WWW.SAVEUR.COM/ARTICLE/TRAVELS/MEXICO-DIANA-KENNEDY-INTERVIEW |accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref>
Kennedy did not have any prior writing experience before the book, but after several rewrites, she published ''The Cuisines of Mexico'' in 1972. This book became a best-seller and is still one of the most authoritative single volumes on Mexican cooking.<ref name=schoeder/><ref name=sgreenberg>{{cite news |author= Sarah Greenberg |title= The Brit who saved Mexican food |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=October 12, 2003 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2003/oct/12/foodanddrink.features6 |accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref>
==Impact== It began to change Americans' understanding of Mexican food, expanding it beyond [[Tex-Mex]] into the various regional cuisines and dishes,<ref name=fiery>{{cite news |author=William Booth |title= Diana Kennedy, fiery chronicler of Mexican food traditions |newspaper=Washington Post |location=Washington, DC |date=January 11, 2011 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/11/AR2011011103354.html |accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref><ref name=sgreenberg/> and is the basis of establishing authentic Mexican food in this country.<ref name=guillermoprieto/> The contents of this book along with two that followed, ''The Tortilla Book'' and ''Mexican Regional Cooking'', were compiled in 2000 into ''The Essential Cuisines of Mexico''. However, this compilation took out many of the stories and photographs of the original book.<ref name=mrotella>{{cite journal |author=Mark Rotella |title= The Essential Cuisines of Mexico |journal=Publishers' Weekly |date=July 24, 2000 |volume=247 |issue=30 |page=85}}</ref> The 1986 a revision of the original book was re-printed and is still available.<ref name=jnathan>{{cite news |author=Joan Nathan |title= The Keeper of the Chilies: Part Hermit, Part Crowd Pleaser: [Biography] |newspaper= New York Times |location= New York |date=July 24, 1996 |page= 4 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Mexican cuisine]]

{{italic title}} [[File:The Record Guide.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Dust-jacket of the 1955 edition]] '''''The Record Guide''''' was an English reference work that listed, described, and evaluated [[gramophone record|gramophone]] recordings of classical music in the 1950s. It was a precursor to modern guides such as ''[[The Penguin Guide to Recorded Classical Music]]''.
==Publication history== The guide was conceived and written by [[Edward Sackville-West, 5th Baron Sackville|Edward Sackville-West]] and the music critic [[Desmond Shawe-Taylor (music critic)|Desmond Shawe-Taylor]]. Their aim, as set out in the preface to the first edition in 1951, was "to try to supply a guide-book to the vast available repertory of the gramophone". The book ran to 763 pages, but nevertheless confined its coverage to records available in Britain in the domestic catalogues up to and including December, 1950. A reviewer wrote of the first edition: "It is not an encyclopaedia … for the principle of it is selective rather than comprehensive. We cannot, therefore, fairly charge the authors with omissions other than those which are inadvertent. The point is made with subtlety in the introduction. 'Inadvertent omissions there are bound to be, in spite of every effort to avoid them but it should not be assumed by the reader that an unquoted record has been simply overlooked. It is much more likely to have been excluded deliberately.'"<ref name=ar/>
The book considers recordings in alphabetical order of composer. Each composer section begins with an introduction assessing and describing the composer's works, after which the recordings are described and evaluated, using a star system, with two stars as the top rating. Of the introductions, the reviewer of ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|The Gramophone]]'' wrote, "these paragraphs vary from a few lines to a couple of pages (the length being unrelated to the importance of the composer) and anyone unfamiliar with the authors would not have to read far before realising that two exceptionally intelligent musical minds had been at work."<ref name=ar>Robertson, Alec, [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/September%201951/11/776047/THE+RECORD+GUIDE#header-logo Review of The Record Guide,] ''The Gramophone'', September 1951, p. 11</ref>
To the keep the guide current, Sackville-West and Shawe-Taylor produced interim updates, ''The Record Year'' in 1952 and 1953. At this time the [[LP record|long playing record]] was being introduced, but records were also being issued in the old 78 r.p.m. format. By 1955 the number of new releases threatened to overwhelm the authors, who recruited two younger colleagues to help them, [[Andrew Porter (music critic)|Andrew Porter]] and William Mann. Between them they produced a full new edition of ''The Record Guide'' in 1955, running to 957 pages,<ref>Robertson, Alec, [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/January%201956/23/802865/The+Record+Guide.+By+Edward+SackvilleWest+and+Desmond+ShaweTaylor.+%28Collins%2C+35s.%29 Review,] ''The Gramophone'', January 1956, p. 23</ref> and a final supplement in 1956.
Four years after the last in the series of ''The Record Guide'' was published, three young musical writers emulated its layout and ''modus operandi'' in ''The Stereo Record Guide'', which has evolved into ''[[The Penguin Guide to Recorded Classical Music]]''
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Record Guide, The}} [[Category:English non-fiction books]] [[Category:Music guides]] [[Category:Classical music discographies]]

page.title: The Sight & Sound Top 50 Greatest Films of All Time

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:The ''Sight & Sound'' Top 50 Greatest Films of All Time}} The following are the "'''Top 50 Greatest Films of All Time'''" according to the worldwide [[opinion poll]]s conducted by ''[[Sight & Sound]]'' and published in the journal's September 2012 issue. They published the critics' list, based on 846 critics, programmers, academics, and distributors,{{cite news |authors=Sight & Sound contributors, [[Ian Christie (film scholar)|Ian Christie]] |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news/50-greatest-films-all-time |title=The 50 Greatest Films of All Time |work=[[Sight & Sound]] |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |origyear=September 2012 |year=August 7, 2017 |accessdate=April 24, 2018}} and the directors' list, based on 358 directors and filmmakers.{{cite web |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news/sight-sound-2012-directors-top-ten |title=Directors’ 10 Greatest Films of All Time |work=Sight & Sound |publisher=British Film Institute |date=December 4, 2014}} ''Sight & Sound'', published by the [[British Film Institute]], has conducted a poll of the [[List of films considered the best|greatest films]] every 10 years since 1952. ==Critics' poll== [[File:Vertigo 1958 trailer Kim Novak at Golden Gate Bridge Fort Point.jpg|thumb|[[Vertigo (film)|''Vertigo'']] (1958)]] In the 2012 critics' poll, ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'' ranked first, replacing ''[[Citizen Kane]]'', which held the top spot in the last five [[decennial]] critics' polls.{{cite news |title=Critics Top Ten Poll 2002 |work=Sight & Sound |publisher=British Film Institute |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/topten/poll/critics.html |accessdate=May 10, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020816030430/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/topten/poll/critics.html |archivedate=August 16, 2002 |deadurl=yes}}{{cite news |last=Brown |first=Mark |title=Vertigo tops greatest film poll, ending reign of Citizen Kane |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/aug/01/vertigo-hitchcock-bfi-greatest-film |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 1, 2012 |accessdate=November 26, 2018}}{{cite web |title=Vertigo is named 'greatest film of all time' |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-19078948 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=August 2, 2012 |accessdate=November 26, 2018}}{{cite news |last=Gleiberman |first=Owen |authorlink=Owen Gleiberman |title='Vertigo' over 'Citizen Kane'? Why the new Sight and Sound critics' poll is full of itself |url=https://ew.com/article/2012/08/07/the-sight-and-sound-poll-is-full-of-it/ |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=August 7, 2012 |accessdate=November 26, 2018}}{{cite news |last=Robey |first=Tim |title=Is Alfred Hitchcock’s thriller Vertigo really the best film ever made? |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2016/04/19/is-alfred-hitchcocks-thriller-vertigo-really-the-best-film-ever/ |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=April 29, 2016 |accessdate=November 26, 2018}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} # ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'' (1958) # ''[[Citizen Kane]]'' (1941) # ''[[Tokyo Story]]'' (1953) # ''[[The Rules of the Game]]'' (1939) # ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'' (1927) # ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' (1968) # ''[[The Searchers]]'' (1956) # ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' (1929) # ''[[The Passion of Joan of Arc]]'' (1928) # ''[[8½]]'' (1963) # ''[[Battleship Potemkin]]'' (1925) # ''[[L'Atalante]]'' (1934) # ''[[Breathless (1960 film)|Breathless]]'' (1960) # ''[[Apocalypse Now]]'' (1979) # ''[[Late Spring]]'' (1949) # ''[[Au Hasard Balthazar]]'' (1966) # ''[[Seven Samurai]]'' (1954) #

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = The young shepherdess, by William-Adolphe Bouguereau.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 220px | title = The Young Shepherdess | alt = | other_language_1 = French | other_title_1 = La jeune bergère | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[William-Adolphe Bouguereau]] | year = {{start date|1885}} <!--remove date template if before 1583 CE --> | material = | height_metric = 157.5 | width_metric = 72.4 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = | museum = [[San Diego Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }} '''''The Young Shepherdess''''' is an 1885 painting by [[William-Adolphe Bouguereau]] (1825–1905). It is owned by the [[San Diego Museum of Art]].
The painting depicts a barefoot young woman in peasant clothing, turned away from but still facing the viewer. She holds a plant in her hands. See also [[The Shepherdess]], a similar painting by the same artist.
This and similar images by the artist attracted collectors in Europe and America because of their nostalgic content.<ref name="frickart">{{cite web |url=http://www.frickart.org/collection_exhibitions/pastexhibitions/86.php |title=Frick Art & Historical Center | Past Exhibitions | In The Studios of Paris WILLIAM BOUGUEREAU His American Students |publisher=frickart.org |accessdate=2015-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829040814/http://www.frickart.org/collection_exhibitions/pastexhibitions/86.php |archivedate=2013-08-29 |df= }}</ref> In such works the artist depicted a variety of poses and expressions, in this case showing the mild curiosity of the girl.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nX0IJ4RNCW4C&pg=PA50&lpg=PA50&dq=The+Young+Shepherdess+is+an+1885+painting+by+William-Adolphe+Bouguereau&source=web&ots=L6oTkVBC3_&sig=LPCcoQRMxBgW3TQBKE-UeXr_b9k&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=39&ct=result#PPA50,M1]{{Dead link|date=August 2015}}{{Dead link|date=August 2015}}</ref>
In portraying a shepherdess Bouguereau is working within the [[pastoral]] mode or theme, as developed by [[ancient Greek]] and [[Hellenistic]] artists and poets. French painters who preceded him in this include [[Claude Lorrain]], [[Poussin]], and [[Watteau]].
==See also== * File:[[:File:William-Adolphe Bouguereau (1825-1905) - Young Shepherdess (1868).jpg|''Jeune bergère'']], 1868 painting with a nearly identical name, also by Bouguereau ==References== {{Reflist}} {{William-Adolphe Bouguereau}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Young Shepherdess}} [[Category:Paintings by William-Adolphe Bouguereau]] [[Category:1885 paintings]] [[Category:Sheep in art]] [[Category:Paintings in San Diego]] [[Category:San Diego Museum of Art]]
