revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Throwback (3-3), Smith.JPG | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 300px | title = Throwback (3/3) | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]] | year = {{Start date|1976}}–{{End date|1979}} | type = [[Aluminum]], painted black | height_metric = 206.4 | width_metric = 395.9 | length_metric = 242.9 | height_imperial = {{frac|81|1|4}} | width_imperial = {{frac|155|7|8}} | length_imperial = {{frac|95|5|8}} | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] | museum = [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] | coordinates = {{coord|38|53|17.34|N|77|1|20.48|W|region:US}} | owner = [[Smithsonian Institution]] }}
'''''Throwback''''' is a public artwork by [[People of the United States|American]] artist [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]], located at the [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]].<ref name="SIRIS">{{cite web | author=Smithsonian | year=1996 | title=Throwback, (sculpture). | work=Inventories of American Painting and Sculpture | publisher=Smithsonian | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!373071~!0#focus | accessdate= 3 January 2010}}</ref> This version is the third of an edition of three in the series with one [[artist's proof]].
==Description== The artwork is constructed sheets of aluminum that have been welded together at precise angles to form a geometric, four-sided, hollow, elongated ring.<ref>{{cite web|title=Throwback Save Outdoor Sculpture! entry|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=134J93Q519U93.3754&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!373071~!68&ri=1&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Smith,+Tony,+1912-1980,+sculptor.&index=AUTHOR&uindex=&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=1|publisher=Inventories of American Painting and Sculpture, Smithsonian American Art Museum|accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> The sculpture is coated with a flat-black industrial fluoropolymer exterior paint applied to achieve a matte finish. Currently sited on a patch of turf in the Sculpture Garden of the Hirshhorn, the sculpture is supported by three subterranean plates with brackets at three points.<ref name="Hirshhorn">Conservation file. 2010. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Washington, D.C.</ref>
==Historical information== In the early to mid-sixties, Smith experimented with tetrahedral and octahedral forms in sculptures such as ''Willy'' and ''Amaryllis''. Over a decade later, Smith returned to these earlier geometries with ''Throwback''. Thus the title of the work alludes to this act of looking back. Smith elaborated on this point, "In a certain sense the piece is unique. I did not have the prospect or opportunity of making a large architectural sculpture so I decided to do something more conventional. I made an object that recalls an earlier period."<ref name="Hunter">Hunter, S. 1979. The sculpture of Tony Smith. In Tony Smith: Ten Elements and Throwback, ed. Pace Gallery. New York: Pace Gallery. 1-9.</ref>
The [[International Paper Company]] was the first to purchase [[Throwback (1/3)|the first sculpture of the edition]] and originally displayed it at the company's New York headquarters.<ref name="Glueck">Glueck, G. 1980. Tony Smith, 68, sculptor of minimalist structures. New York Times, December 27.</ref> It is now owned by the [[City of New York]] and on display at 1166 Avenue of the Americas.
The second version was purchased by [[San Francisco Museum of Modern Art]] and is currently on display.<ref name="SFMOMA">{{cite web | author=San Francisco Museum of Art | year=2010 | title=Tony Smith | work=Our Collection | publisher=SFMOMA | url=http://www.sfmoma.org/artwork/282 | accessdate= 3 January 2010}}</ref> The artists proof has not been fabricated.
Several other versions of the work exist. In 1976, a smaller (62 × 150 inches), unique version of the work was installed at [[Grove Isle]], Coconut Grove, Florida. A full-scale plywood model, painted black, was created for exhibition at the [[Pace Gallery]] in 1979. A cardboard maquette (measuring 13 1/2 × 32 1/2 × 16 inches) was intended to serve as the model of an edition of 9 bronzes.<ref name="McClintic">McClintic, M. 1979. Memorandum: propose acquisition of Throwback, 28 September 1979. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden Archives, Washington, D.C.</ref> However, the maquette was ultimately produced in a numbered edition of 6.
===Acquisition=== While the work is dated from 1976–1977, the Hirshhorn's edition of the work was acquired from the Pace Gallery in 1980. [[Lippincott, Inc]] fabricated the sculpture in North Haven, Connecticut, in the same year.<ref name="Glimcher">Glimcher, A.B. 1979. Letter from Arnold B. Glimcher to Abram Lerner, 12 December 1979. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden Archives, Washington, D.C.</ref>
==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 2]] * [[List of Tony Smith sculptures]] * [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Public art/TheArtistResearchProject/TonySmith|The Tony Smith Artist Research Project in Wikipedia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bluffton.edu/~sullivanm/hirshhorn/hirshhorn7.html Mary Ann Sullivan's images of ''Throwback'']
{{Tony Smith}} {{Washington, D.C.}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Throwback (3 3)}} [[Category:Sculptures by Tony Smith]] [[Category:1979 sculptures]] [[Category:Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] [[Category:Sculptures of the Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:Abstract sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Aluminum sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Modernist sculpture]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Yildiz Park 03.jpg|thumb|Main entrance to Yıldız Park]] '''Yıldız Park''' ({{lang-tr|Yıldız Parkı}}) is a historical, [[urban park]] in [[Beşiktaş]] district of [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]]. It is one of the largest public parks in Istanbul. The park is located in [[Yıldız]] quarter between the palaces of [[Yıldız Palace|Yıldız]] and [[Çırağan Palace|Çırağan]].
==History== [[Image:Ciragan Palace 1840.JPG|thumb|Painting of [[Çırağan Palace]] with the hilly slopes of Yıldız Park, seen from the Bosphorus (1840)]] Yıldız Park was once part of the imperial garden of [[Yıldız Palace]]. Extending down the slopes from the palace, this walled park was reserved only for palace dwellers during the reign of Sultan [[Abdulhamid II]].
The area of Yıldız used to be a forest in [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] times. Starting during the reign of [[Suleiman the Magnificent]], the sultans made it their hunting grounds. In the next centuries, it remained as a grove behind the seaside palaces. The neighbourhood began to flourish in the wake of construction of the palace in the 19th century. It took its name from the first pavilion, namely ''Yıldız Kasrı'', commissioned by [[Selim III]] in early 19th century.
The {{convert|25|acre|km2|sing=on}} of the palace's external garden were surrounded by high walls and detached from a grove during the reign of [[Abdulhamid II]] in the 19th century. A small artificial lake, pavilions, summer houses and a porcelain factory were established in this section.
==Today== [[Image:Yildiz Park 02.jpg|thumb|Inside Yıldız Park with the way to the porcelain manufactury]] Currently Yıldız Park is a beautiful garden complex with set in a very large park of flowers, plants and trees, gathered from every part of the world dating from the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] era. Park grounds offer panoramic views of the [[Bosphorus]]. The park is a popular picnic place especially for the weekends. Two beautiful old [[pavilions]], namely Çadır and Malta pavilions, are used to rest, drink tea, eat breakfast and have lunch.
The park is separated into two sections, the outer section is open to the public and comprises the Şale, Çadır and [[Malta Pavilion|Malta]] pavilions and the still-operating Yıldız porcelain factory. The vegetation of the park includes [[magnolia]], [[bay leaves]], [[Judas Tree (Cercis siliquastrum)|Judas tree]]s, silver limes and [[Aesculus|horse-chestnuts]]. Furthermore, the park shelters [[oak]], [[cypress]], [[pine]], [[taxus|yew]], [[Cedar wood|cedar]] and [[ash tree]]s. Besides, the outer section has two man-made lakes.
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Cadir Kiosk garden March 2008b.JPG|Çadır Pavilion within the grounds of the park Image:Malta Pavilion 01.jpg|[[Malta Kiosk]], now open to the public Image:Sale Pavilion 01.jpg|Façade of the main building of Şale Pavilion Image:Yildiz Porcelain Factory 01.jpg|Yıldız Porcelain and Tile manufactury complex </gallery>
==See also== * [[Yıldız Clock Tower]]
==References== * Governorate of Istanbul official website - [https://web.archive.org/web/20070629190849/http://www.istanbul.gov.tr/Default.aspx?pid=359 ''Yıldız Palace and Park'']
==External links== {{commonscat-inline}} * Planetware.com - [https://web.archive.org/web/20071105163127/http://www.planetware.com/istanbul/yildiz-park-tr-is-yp.htm ''Yıldız Park''] * YildizParki.com - [https://web.archive.org/web/20080615003634/http://www.yildizparki.com/ ''Istanbul Yıldız Parkı'']
